overview:
Alan started in the tech field at age 19 when, while working on the “labor gang” by the blast furnace in a steel mill, he decided that he wanted a job that would assure an air conditioned environment. When he learned that the steel mill where he worked kept its IBM 360s in a totally air conditioned environment, he decided to learn COBOL and Fortran. He then proceeded to work his way through college and law school programming IBM mainframes for banks, insurance companies, tech companies and his undergrad and professional schools.

After a 30+ year diversion in the legal profession, where he was a partner and co-chair of the international litigation/arbitration practice at Jone Day, a Global 10 firm, he has returned to his roots to start InterActive Matrix, a software company in stealth mode designing what it hopes to be to CRM and CMS software what the Macintosh was to the PC.
